target was

As the planes

The anti-aircraft shells made black puffs of smoke in

but none exploded near enough to do any damage

The bombs were dropped
inside

Here in this room all lights are
and there is no heat.
am writing next to a window,
one of two such openings with a door between,
a small
amount of light filters in from the courtyard over the double row
of sand bage piled celling high in front of the door and windows.
room is one set aside
for meetings and conferences.
It is on the first
floor of the four storied magnificent Ministry of Communications building
built in modern steel and concrete to resemble the old Chinese architec-
ture.
I am told that
the floor above us is bomb-proof.
I hope that
statement is true for the siren outside is at this moment screaming the
signal which warns that another raid is on the way.
Outposts with
telephone connections
to the siren stations are flung around Nanking in
a circle so that
warnings are given about 15 minutes before the planes get
To augment the siren a small boy walked through
the corridor with
an alarm clock ringing vociferously the while he wound it vigorously.
Literally an alarm
clock!
We had our board meeting in the candle light -
all lights are off during raids - and I'll confess that it was a bit eerie
and disconcerting until we got the "all clear"
The Ministry
Building is
checked as an objective on all the Jap maps which have been
taken from planes shot down.
Our meeting was a total loss so far as
getting anything accomplished along lines desired by us.
Had dinner at the Metropolitan Hotel with some of my American
all of whom are here trying to get "their share" (meaning
planes, motors and parts.
They are all worried about deliveries and their
schemes
are legion for beating the Japanese blockade and various American
restrictive export regulations.
